body:
@mayankshriv 
> - Seems like I need to do mvn install to see the UI changes (as in, IDE does not build on its own). If there's a way to automate that, it would be nice.

Will check that out and see what can be done but as part of another PR.

> - Edit Tag does not seem to take the new tag. Edit Config works for editing/adding tags.

We need to press `Enter`, `Space` or `Comma (,)` to create tag pills, and only then that Tag will be saved. Users can add N number of tags and that's the reason the user needs to do an extra step.

> - Drop: Says instance cannot be dropped as it is live.

UI is showing the status sent by the backend on hitting the drop API.
LGTM!

> @mayankshriv
> 
> > * Seems like I need to do mvn install to see the UI changes (as in, IDE does not build on its own). If there's a way to automate that, it would be nice.
> 
> Will check that out and see what can be done but as part of another PR.
> 
> > * Edit Tag does not seem to take the new tag. Edit Config works for editing/adding tags.
> 
> We need to press `Enter`, `Space` or `Comma (,)` to create tag pills, and only then that Tag will be saved. Users can add N number of tags and that's the reason the user needs to do an extra step.
> 
> > * Drop: Says instance cannot be dropped as it is live.
> 
> UI is showing the status sent by the backend on hitting the drop API.

Hey @shahsank3t , Iâ€™m seeing similar behavior as reported by Mayank for Edit Tags, but only for Server case. Broker works fine for me. Even in Server case, remove tag worked and edit config worked.

@mayankshriv the drop behavior is correct. I verified that the backend is returning the message. Something seems off at the backend side. I remember we used to be able to drop instances after table has been deleted. Will check that out.

@Jackie-Jiang  I think the current implementation assumes the primary key cannot be the time column. Also, in reality, it does not quite make sense to use the time column as the primary key? If the intention is to use a later record to overwrite a previous one with the same timestamp, then it won't work for Pinot as the update behavior of the records with same timestamp is undefined.

> We cannot exclude either one of them because `tyrus` is needed to stream external data and `jersey-container-grizzly2-http` is needed to start the web server.

You can exclude the underlying dependencies of them to resolve the version conflict right?

@yupeng9 There could be multiple time columns with different granularity, and user can potentially use the upsert to dedup the records if the upstream side might produce duplicate records. Also, `DATE_TIME` field does not mean the field is the timestamp.

> I see. Then we need to look at the `timeColumnName` of table config to determine the primary.

IMO, we don't need to validate that primary key does not contain time column (I can see a valid dedup use case that needs such setting). We can validate that all the primary key columns exist in the schema.
sg. Removed.

@npawar @mayankshriv 
made the changes so we no longer need to press "Enter", "Space" or "Comma" to make a chip before saving tags.

Egh sorry, this was a bit of noise. I completely mixed up issues we were seeing -- instead we were seeing expected behaviour (broker pruning and immedately returning zero segments, which was initially unexpected but we later realized we had only partially uploaded data).

@jackjlli I see the problem, basically `tyrus` copied the code from `grizzly` and put it in one package. If you upgrade `tyrus` to `1.15` to be compatible with `grizzly 2.4.4`, then the problem should be solved
@Jackie-Jiang Thanks for looking into it. I've opened a new PR to bump up the Tyrus version to 1.15 (https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/6162). Once that's merged, we can close this PR.

Basic feature (move from realtime to offline using minions) is complete.
Let's open new issues for enhancements related to using hadoop map reduce/spark etc.

Discussed offline and suggested:
1. Adding an array of locks
2. Changing the helix update to not use the default backoff timer (that backs off for 1s and more exponentially). Throughput will suffer. Better to have smaller backoffs with randomness between 100 and 200ms (say), and more retries.

Also, `avg` sort of mislabels the API. What is returned (as per implementation) is not the average of all the consuming segments, but the historical average of what a typical consuming segment may have used. I want to make sure that this is what you are looking for, and we can name it appropriately (I don't have a name, of course).

Lastly, if you are building an internal (pinot) tool, you can copy the file over and examine it as well. Perhaps you already considered this and discarded the idea, but just wanted to be sure that you are aware of it.

Can we use the existing issue?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/issues/5664
@jackjlli Should we keep this issue open to track all the PRs improving the test coverage?

> Can we make the sql queries one-to-one mapping with the pql queries?

It's a good idea but the thing is that there are some restrictions in SQL comparisons, e.g. in SQL we skip the comparison of MV columns. So if we make it one to one mapping, the number of queries will be reduced. 
Plus, SQL requires the order by column to be appeared in the selection clause, which requires us to modify the original queries. And the selection queries without order by are missing in the original query files as well, as the logic of comparing selection w/o order by is missing in the code.
@Jackie-Jiang Yes, we should keep it open. The issue auto closes itself when some PR is merged.

How can Pinot know the status of job running outside the cluster

> How can Pinot know the status of job running outside the cluster

Similarly to the API of pushing segment, there will be a API call made at the end of the job, no matter whether the job succeeded or failed. This call includes the job status like job name, job execution time, job failed, or any exception message.
So this is segmentstatus not the status of the job rt

> So this is segment status not the status of the job rt

Not just the segment status. E.g. the job could fail at failing to find the table config, or the job can failed at generating segments, or the job succeeded after pushing all 100 segments. This information can be uploaded to Pinot by this API.

Design document for a star schema join involving a fact table and small size dim tables: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1InWmxbRqwcqIakzvoEWHLxtX4XR9H5L01256EbAUHV8/edit?usp=sharing

This design require the dim table to be available on each host hence the restriction on size. Future work for this will involve lifting this restriction by implementing a broadcast join operator, which will enable larger and partitioned dim tables and help solve more generic join use cases.
